title: David Collins (lieutenant governor)
text:
Colonel David Collins (3 March 1756 – 24 March 1810) was a <a href="British%20Marine">British Marine</a> officer who was appointed as Judge-Advocate to the new colony being established in <a href="Botany%20Bay">Botany Bay</a>. He sailed with Governor <a href="Arthur%20Phillip">Arthur Phillip</a>, on the <a href="First%20Fleet">First Fleet</a> to establish a penal colony at what is now <a href="Sydney">Sydney</a>. He became secretary to the first couple of Governors, later being appointed to start a secondary colony where he founded the city of <a href="Hobart">Hobart</a> as the founding Lieutenant Governor of <a href="Van%20Diemen%27s%20Land">Van Diemen's Land</a> (later becoming the state of <a href="Tasmania">Tasmania</a>).
Early life and military career.
David Collins was born 3 March 1756 in London, the third child of Arthur Tooker Collins (1718–1793), an officer of <a href="Royal%20Marines">marines</a> (later major-general) and Henrietta Caroline née Fraser (died 1807). His grandfather <a href="Arthur%20Collins%20%28antiquarian%29">Arthur Collins</a> (1684-1760) was author of "<a href="Collins%27s%20Peerage%20of%20England">Collins's Peerage of England</a>".
"A Compendium of Irish Biography" (1878), states that he was born at the home of his maternal grandparents in <a href="County%20Offaly">County Offaly</a>, then known as King's County. Collins went to <a href="Exeter%20Grammar%20School">Exeter Grammar School</a> before joining the Royal Marines as an <a href="Ensign%20%28rank%29">ensign</a> at the age of 14. He was promoted <a href="second%20lieutenant">second lieutenant</a> on 20 February 1771. He was serving aboard when <a href="Caroline%20Matilda%20of%20Great%20Britain">Queen Matilda of Denmark</a> was dramatically rescued.
Collins went to North America early in 1775, and fought at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Bunker%20Hill">Battle of Bunker Hill</a>, where the British suffered heavy casualties, but held the heights of <a href="Charlestown%2C%20Massachusetts">Charlestown</a>. He was promoted to <a href="first%20lieutenant">first lieutenant</a> the following week.
By November 1776, he was stationed at <a href="Halifax%2C%20Nova%20Scotia">Halifax</a>, <a href="Nova%20Scotia">Nova Scotia</a>, where he met and then married <a href="Maria%20Stuart%20Collins">Mary (Maria Stuart) Proctor</a>, the daughter of Captain <a href="Charles%20Procter">Charles Proctor</a>, on 13 June 1777. He was promoted <a href="captain-lieutenant">captain-lieutenant</a> in August 1779, and outright <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">Captain</a> by July 1780. In February 1781, he joined in the Channel Squadron, but did not enjoy being at sea.
Australia.
New South Wales.
In October 1786, after three years on half-pay stationed at <a href="Chatham%20Dockyard">Chatham</a>, Collins volunteered for service in the proposed <a href="penal%20colony">penal colony</a> of New South Wales. On 29 November, and despite a lack of legal training, he was named <a href="Judge%20Advocate%20of%20New%20South%20Wales">Judge Advocate</a> for the new colony and chief judge for a military court administering the <a href="New%20South%20Wales%20Marine%20Corps">New South Wales Marine Corps</a>. In May 1787 he sailed aboard the <a href="First%20Fleet">First Fleet</a>, reaching Sydney Cove in January 1788.
In June or July 1788, <a href="Arthur%20Phillip">Governor Phillip</a> appointed Collins as the Secretary to the Governor, or Secretary to the <a href="Colony%20of%20New%20South%20Wales">Colony</a> as the position was sometimes called. Collins filled the three roles of Secretary, Judge Advocate and Lieutenant Governor until he left the colony for England in 1796.
Victoria and Tasmania.
Collins also established the first, short-lived settlement in what is now the state of <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a> at <a href="Sullivan%20Bay%2C%20Victoria">Sullivan Bay</a> on <a href="Port%20Phillip">Port Phillip</a> in 1803. He sailed from England in April aboard , arriving at Port Phillip in October to found a <a href="penal%20colony">penal colony</a>. After landing at Sullivan Bay near present-day <a href="Sorrento%2C%20Victoria">Sorrento</a>, he sent First Lieutenant <a href="James%20Hingston%20Tuckey">James Hingston Tuckey</a> of the "Calcutta" to explore <a href="Port%20Phillip">Port Phillip</a>. Tuckey's report, and Collins' own dissatisfaction with the site chosen, prompted him to write to <a href="Philip%20Gidley%20King">Governor King</a>, seeking permission to remove the settlement. When King agreed, Collins decided to move the colony to the <a href="Derwent%20River%20%28Tasmania%29">Derwent River</a>, on the island of <a href="Van%20Diemen%27s%20Land">Van Diemen's Land</a> (Tasmania). He arrived there in February 1804 on <a href="Ocean%20%281794%20ship%29">"Ocean"</a>, and established what would become the town of <a href="Hobart">Hobart</a>.
Collins left no published account of his work as Lieutenant-Governor at <a href="Port%20Phillip">Port Phillip</a>, nor later as the founder of <a href="Hobart%2C%20Tasmania">Hobart</a>.
Legacy.
Collins has given his name to <a href="Collinsvale%2C%20Tasmania">Collinsvale</a> in Tasmania, <a href="Collins%20Street%2C%20Melbourne">Collins Street</a>, Melbourne, Collins Parade, Sorrento (adjacent to the site of the failed settlement) and <a href="Collins%20Street%2C%20Hobart">Collins Street</a>, Hobart. At Exeter Grammar School, now known as <a href="Exeter%20School">Exeter School</a>, where he was educated, there is a <a href="House%20system">house</a> named after him.
Collins was portrayed by <a href="David%20Dawson%20%28actor%29">David Dawson</a> in the 2015 TV series "<a href="Banished%20%28TV%20series%29">Banished</a>".
